lexUnit.name: hatch.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: conspire to devise (a plot or plan).

sentence.text: While I sulked in the tent , nursing my wounds and recovering from the thorough sandbagging , Mick was hatching a plan .
The court heard that a desperate financial crisis and debts of more than Â£40,000 drove Shooter to hatch his unsuccessful plot .
Can you really imagine anyone hatching a devious plot to take over the school at his age ? "
TORY Euro rebels are hatching a secret plot to oust Premier John Major .
Police believe this was when he hatched his plot to kill .
In desperation , Forman had hatched the scheme to rob the bank .
For the following day our leader hatched a Grand Tour .
Meanwhile Mrs hatched her plans , abetted by the man of the world .
And Ten-huc was no doubt hatching his own plots .
Evil things crawled out of basements , and plots were hatched there by the half-crazed .
In November 1717 Byng and his ships returned home , to counter another , far more threatening , invasion plot now being hatched by a far older enemy of England , Spain .
In the following year , however , a plot was hatched by the English and their supporters , which regained for them control of the city .
Meanwhile , a serious conspiracy against the Republic was being hatched .
And , behind the scenes in some superstores , plans are being hatched to ban battery eggs .
Plans for the first of the Italian journeys had been hatched in Vienna , and Leopold had obtained letters of recommendation from the Emperor , among others .
At the same time he and some of the Shahs entourage , including Colonel Jahanbini , hatched a simple and dramatic plot .
Now , through their domination of the London Labour Party , they were running it , and they started putting into practice schemes hatched during their long hours in drab municipal offices .
